content: Not sure why you think that neoliberalism is ignored by the rest of the world when it is the dominant theory taught in all western universities and business schools — to the extent that the students at Manchester Universtity in the UK had to set up their own, ‘Post Crash Club’ to discuss the economics of the 2008 crash because it wasn’t being taught — and when one lecturer tried to teach ‘heterodox’ economics (as opposed to the orthodoxy of neoliberalism) he was taken off the teaching roster on the grounds that he was ‘inciting revolt’. I am completing a Masters in ‘Economics for Transition’ at Schumacher College, part of the University of Plymouth — our course is one of the very few — if not the only one — in the world that starts from the premise that neoliberalism is broken and we need a new model. If you’re looking for that model, I can only recommend Kate Raworth’s newly published book: Doughnut Economics, 7 ways to think like a 21st century economist. She has been described as the John Meynard Keynes of the 21st century and her book is a perfect critique of neoliberalism, followed by a road map away from it. She’ll be touring in the US soon. https://www.amazon.co.uk/Doughnut-Economics-Seven-21st-Century-Economist/dp/1847941370
